definitions: move among and interact with people in a social gathering or public place
combine or mix different things together so they become indistinguishable from each other
examples: The host mingled with guests throughout the evening reception
Students were encouraged to mingle during the orientation week
The chef carefully mingled spices into the aromatic sauce
Different cultural traditions mingle beautifully in this diverse neighborhood

definitions: reduce something to the smallest possible amount, extent, or degree through careful management
deliberately represent something as less important or serious than it actually is
examples: The company implemented new procedures to minimise operational costs
We need to minimise environmental damage during construction
Politicians often minimise their mistakes during press conferences
Don't minimise the impact this decision will have on employees

definitions: reduce something to the smallest possible amount, extent, or degree through careful management
deliberately represent something as less important or serious than it actually is
examples: Engineers worked to minimize heat loss in the building design
The new software helps minimize errors in data entry
He tried to minimize his role in the failed project
The report seemed to minimize the severity of the crisis

definitions: attend to the needs of someone by providing care, help, or service
perform religious duties and ceremonies as a member of the clergy
examples: Nurses ministered to wounded soldiers throughout the night
Volunteers minister to homeless people at the shelter
Father Johnson has ministered at this church for twenty years
The chaplain ministers to patients in the hospital

definitions: pursue an academic subject as a secondary area of specialization in college or university
examples: She decided to minor in philosophy while majoring in engineering
Many business students minor in a foreign language

definitions: manufacture coins or medals by stamping metal in an official government facility
create or produce something new, especially in large quantities or as if new
examples: The government mints new coins every year at the facility
This factory minted commemorative medals for the Olympics
Silicon Valley continues to mint new millionaires every year
The author minted several memorable phrases in her latest novel

definitions: cause to become stuck or trapped in soft, wet, muddy ground
involve someone or something in a difficult, complicated, or unpleasant situation
examples: The heavy truck was mired in deep mud after the storm
Their vehicles became mired in the swampy terrain
The company has been mired in legal disputes for years
Don't let yourself get mired in office politics

definitions: show a reflection of something as a mirror does with light or images
match, copy, or correspond exactly to something else in characteristics or behavior
examples: The calm lake perfectly mirrored the surrounding mountains
Glass buildings mirror the sky and clouds above
His reaction mirrored exactly what I was feeling inside
Stock prices often mirror consumer confidence levels

definitions: behave in an improper or unprofessional manner, especially in violation of rules or standards
examples: The officer was accused of misconducting himself during the arrest
Several employees were fired for misconducting themselves at the conference

definitions: fail to fire or explode properly when a gun trigger is pulled or engine cylinder ignites
fail to produce the intended result or have the desired effect on something
examples: The old pistol misfired when he pulled the trigger
One cylinder in the engine keeps misfiring
The marketing campaign completely misfired with younger consumers
His attempt at humor misfired and offended the audience

definitions: cause someone to have a wrong idea or impression about something through deception or error
guide someone in the wrong direction either physically or metaphorically
examples: The false advertisement deliberately misled consumers about product quality
Don't let his confident manner mislead you about his expertise
The faulty map misled hikers into dangerous terrain
Bad advice can mislead students in their career choices

definitions: put together or combine things that do not correspond or suit each other properly
examples: Someone mismatched all the socks in the laundry basket
The database system mismatched customer orders with wrong addresses

definitions: read written or printed text incorrectly by making errors in recognition or pronunciation
interpret or understand a situation, person, or signal incorrectly
examples: The student misread the question and gave the wrong answer
I misread the street sign and took the wrong turn
She completely misread his intentions and felt embarrassed later
Investors misread market signals and lost significant money

definitions: cover or spray something with a fine spray of water droplets or vapor
become covered with mist or condensation, especially becoming clouded or obscured
examples: The gardener misted the delicate orchids every morning
She misted her face with cooling spray
The bathroom mirror misted over during the hot shower
Her eyes misted with tears during the emotional scene

definitions: wrongly identify someone or something as being a different person or thing
examples: People often mistake him for his famous brother at events
I mistook your coat for mine in the darkness

definitions: feel no trust or confidence in someone or something due to suspicion or doubt
examples: After being deceived, she mistrusts all financial advisors now
Many citizens mistrust government officials and their promises

definitions: use something in the wrong way or for the wrong purpose, often causing harm or waste
examples: The manager misused company funds for personal expenses
Many people misuse antibiotics by not completing the full course

definitions: join two pieces of material at an angle, typically forty-five degrees, in carpentry or construction
examples: The carpenter carefully mitered the corners of the picture frame
You need to miter these boards for a perfect fit

definitions: make something bad less severe, serious, or painful through specific actions or measures
examples: New safety measures will mitigate the risk of workplace accidents
The government introduced policies to mitigate economic damage from the crisis

definitions: combine two or more substances so that they become a single substance or blend
associate or mingle socially with other people in social situations
combine different recordings, sounds, or elements to create a unified product
examples: Mix the flour and water until you get smooth dough
The bartender mixed several ingredients to create the cocktail
She doesn't mix well with her new colleagues yet
The children from different schools mixed easily at camp
The engineer mixed the tracks to create the final recording
The DJ mixed different songs seamlessly during the performance

definitions: make a long, low sound expressing physical or emotional pain, discomfort, or pleasure
complain or grumble about something in an annoying or repetitive way
examples: The injured player moaned in pain on the field
Wind moaned through the old house during the storm
She constantly moans about her workload to anyone who listens
Stop moaning and start finding solutions to the problem

definitions: crowd around someone or something in an aggressive, excited, or uncontrolled way
examples: Fans mobbed the celebrity as she left the theater
Reporters mobbed the politician after the shocking announcement

definitions: organize and prepare people or resources for a particular purpose or action
prepare and organize troops or military resources for active service or war
examples: The community mobilised volunteers to help flood victims immediately
Activists mobilised support for the environmental protection campaign
The government mobilised reserve forces during the national emergency
Several countries mobilised their armies along the border

definitions: organize and prepare people or resources for a particular purpose or action
prepare and organize troops or military resources for active service or war
examples: The organization mobilized thousands of protesters for the march
We need to mobilize public opinion on this issue
The president mobilized the national guard to assist with disaster relief
Nations quickly mobilized their military forces

definitions: tease or laugh at someone in a scornful or contemptuous manner
imitate someone or something in an exaggerated way to make fun of them
examples: The bullies mocked him for his unusual accent
Critics mocked the mayor's latest policy proposal
The comedian brilliantly mocked the politician's speaking style
Children often mock their teachers behind their backs

definitions: create a representation or simulation of something for study or demonstration purposes
display clothes or products by wearing or using them for promotional purposes
work as a professional model displaying clothes or products
examples: Scientists model climate change using complex computer simulations
The architect modeled the new building in 3D software
She modeled the latest fashion collection at the runway show
He modeled sportswear for the catalog photoshoot
She has modeled professionally for major fashion brands since college
He models part-time while studying at university

definitions: make or become less extreme, intense, or violent through conscious control or intervention
preside over a discussion or debate ensuring fairness and proper procedure
examples: The new policies aim to moderate income inequality
You should moderate your drinking at the company party
She will moderate the panel discussion at tomorrow's conference
The professor moderated the heated debate between students

definitions: adapt something to modern needs or habits by updating methods, equipment, or ideas
examples: The company needs to modernise its manufacturing processes urgently
They modernised the historic building while preserving its character

definitions: adapt something to modern needs or habits by updating methods, equipment, or ideas
examples: The military plans to modernize its aging fleet of aircraft
Many schools are modernizing their teaching methods with technology

definitions: make partial or minor changes to something in order to improve it or make it suitable
examples: Engineers modified the design to improve fuel efficiency significantly
You can modify the recipe according to your dietary needs

definitions: adjust or regulate the strength, tone, or pitch of something, especially voice or signal
change from one musical key to another in a smooth transition
examples: The speaker modulated her voice to emphasize important points
The device modulates radio signals for clearer transmission
The composer skillfully modulated from C major to G major
Jazz musicians often modulate between different keys during improvisation

definitions: shape a soft or malleable substance into a particular form using hands or tools
influence the formation or development of someone's character, abilities, or behavior
examples: The potter molded clay into beautiful ceramic bowls
Children love to mold figures from modeling clay
Great teachers mold young minds through inspiration and guidance
His experiences in the military molded his leadership style

definitions: assault or abuse someone, especially sexually, or harass them in an aggressive way
examples: The man was arrested for molesting children in the neighborhood
Security guards prevented anyone from molesting the visiting dignitaries

definitions: shed old feathers, hair, or skin periodically to make way for new growth
examples: Birds molt their feathers once or twice each year
The snake will molt its skin as it grows larger

definitions: promote or trade in something, typically something undesirable or controversial
examples: Politicians accused their opponents of mongering fear before elections
Tabloid newspapers often monger gossip about celebrities

definitions: observe and check the progress or quality of something over a period of time
examples: Nurses monitor patients' vital signs throughout the night
The security team monitors all entrances twenty-four hours daily

definitions: behave in a silly or playful way, often causing minor trouble
tamper or interfere with something, especially machinery or equipment
examples: The kids were monkeying around in the backyard all afternoon
Stop monkeying and focus on your homework
Don't monkey with the thermostat settings without asking first
Someone has been monkeying with my computer files

definitions: obtain exclusive possession or control of something, preventing others from having access
examples: Large corporations often monopolize entire markets through aggressive tactics
She tends to monopolize conversations at social gatherings

definitions: make the characteristic deep vocal sound that a cow produces
examples: The cows mooed loudly when the farmer arrived with feed
We could hear cattle mooing in the distant pasture

definitions: work at a second job, typically secretly and often at night, in addition to regular employment
examples: The teacher moonlights as a bartender to pay off student loans
Many police officers moonlight as security guards

definitions: secure a boat or ship by attaching it to the shore or anchor
attach or secure something firmly to a fixed point or position
examples: The captain moored the yacht at the marina for repairs
Several boats were moored along the wooden dock
The balloon was moored to prevent it drifting away
They moored the floating platform with heavy chains

definitions: raise a question or topic for discussion or debate, especially a hypothetical one
examples: The committee mooted several proposals for reducing carbon emissions
Someone mooted the idea of working from home permanently

definitions: clean a floor or surface using a mop with water or cleaning solution
wipe or remove liquid from something using an absorbent material
examples: The janitor mops the hallways every evening after classes
She mopped the kitchen floor until it sparkled
He mopped sweat from his forehead during the intense workout
Nurses mopped blood from the emergency room floor

definitions: undergo or cause to undergo a gradual transformation from one form or shape into another
examples: The caterpillar morphs into a butterfly through metamorphosis
Digital technology allows images to morph seamlessly into different shapes

definitions: attack or bombard a place using mortar shells fired from military weapons
join bricks or stones together using mortar as a binding material
examples: Enemy forces mortared the base throughout the night
The village was heavily mortared during the conflict
The mason carefully mortared each brick into place
Workers mortared the stone walls of the ancient building

definitions: borrow money from a bank using property as security for the loan repayment
examples: They mortgaged their house to start a new business venture
Many people mortgage property to finance their children's education

definitions: care for and protect someone in a maternal way, sometimes excessively
give birth to or be the mother of a child
examples: She tends to mother all her younger colleagues at work
Stop mothering me; I can take care of myself
She mothered three children and adopted two more
The cat mothered a litter of six kittens

definitions: direct or signal someone to do something using a movement or gesture
examples: The guard motioned us to move forward through the gate
She motioned for everyone to be quiet during the presentation

definitions: provide someone with a reason or incentive for doing something
stimulate someone's interest or enthusiasm for doing something
examples: The bonus system motivates employees to exceed their targets
What motivated you to change careers at this stage?
The coach knows how to motivate players before important games
Teachers must find creative ways to motivate reluctant students

definitions: travel in a motor vehicle, especially in a leisurely or steady way
examples: We motored along the coastal highway enjoying the scenery
The yacht motored into the harbor at sunset
